trans-unit.source: How to use the service management API (Python) - feature guide
trans-unit.target: How to use the service management API (Python) - feature guide

trans-unit.source: Learn how to programmatically perform common service management tasks from Python.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to programmatically perform common service management tasks from Python.

trans-unit.source: How to use Service Management from Python
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Management from Python

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to programmatically perform common service management tasks from Python.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to programmatically perform common service management tasks from Python.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceManagementService class in the Azure SDK for Python[download-sdk-python] supports programmatic access to much of the service management-related functionality that is available in the management portal[management-portal] (such as creating, updating, and deleting cloud services, deployments, data management services and virtual machines).
trans-unit.target: The ServiceManagementService class in the Azure SDK for Python[download-sdk-python] supports programmatic access to much of the service management-related functionality that is available in the management portal[management-portal] (such as creating, updating, and deleting cloud services, deployments, data management services and virtual machines).

trans-unit.source: This functionality can be useful in building applications that need programmatic access to service management.
trans-unit.target: This functionality can be useful in building applications that need programmatic access to service management.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>What is Service Management
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>What is Service Management

trans-unit.source: The Service Management API provides programmatic access to much of the service management functionality available through the <link><linkText>management portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The Service Management API provides programmatic access to much of the service management functionality available through the <link><linkText>management portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The Azure SDK for Python allows you to manage your cloud services and storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SDK for Python allows you to manage your cloud services and storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: To use the Service Management API, you will need to <link><linkText>create an Azure account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To use the Service Management API, you will need to <link><linkText>create an Azure account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Concepts
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Concepts

trans-unit.source: The Azure SDK for Python wraps the <link><linkText>Azure Service Management API[svc-mgmt-rest-api]</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a REST API.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SDK for Python wraps the <link><linkText>Azure Service Management API[svc-mgmt-rest-api]</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a REST API.

trans-unit.source: All API operations are performed over SSL and mutually authenticated using X.509 v3 certificates.
trans-unit.target: All API operations are performed over SSL and mutually authenticated using X.509 v3 certificates.

trans-unit.source: The management service may be accessed from within a service running in Azure, or directly over the Internet from any application that can send an HTTPS request and receive an HTTPS response.
trans-unit.target: The management service may be accessed from within a service running in Azure, or directly over the Internet from any application that can send an HTTPS request and receive an HTTPS response.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Connect to service management
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Connect to service management

trans-unit.source: To connect to the Service Management endpoint, you need your Azure subscription ID and a valid management certificate.
trans-unit.target: To connect to the Service Management endpoint, you need your Azure subscription ID and a valid management certificate.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain your subscription ID through the <link><linkText>management portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can obtain your subscription ID through the <link><linkText>management portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Since Azure SDK for Python v0.8.0, it is now possible to use certificates created with OpenSSL when running on Windows.
trans-unit.target: Since Azure SDK for Python v0.8.0, it is now possible to use certificates created with OpenSSL when running on Windows.

trans-unit.source: This requires Python 2.7.4 or later.
trans-unit.target: This requires Python 2.7.4 or later.

trans-unit.source: We recommend users to use OpenSSL instead of .pfx, since support for .pfx certificates will likely be removed in the future.
trans-unit.target: We recommend users to use OpenSSL instead of .pfx, since support for .pfx certificates will likely be removed in the future.

trans-unit.source: Management certificates on Windows/Mac/Linux (OpenSSL)
trans-unit.target: Management certificates on Windows/Mac/Linux (OpenSSL)

trans-unit.source: You can use <link><linkText>OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link> to create your management certificate.
trans-unit.target: You can use <link><linkText>OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link> to create your management certificate.

trans-unit.source: You actually need to create two certificates, one for the server (a .cer file) and one for the client (a .pem file).
trans-unit.target: You actually need to create two certificates, one for the server (a .cer file) and one for the client (a .pem file).

trans-unit.source: To create the .pem file, execute this:
trans-unit.target: To create the .pem file, execute this:

trans-unit.source: To create the .cer certificate, execute this:
trans-unit.target: To create the .cer certificate, execute this:

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure certificates, see <link><linkText>Managing Certificates in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure certificates, see <link><linkText>Managing Certificates in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For a complete description of OpenSSL parameters, see the documentation at <link><linkText>http://www.openssl.org/docs/apps/openssl.html</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For a complete description of OpenSSL parameters, see the documentation at <link><linkText>http://www.openssl.org/docs/apps/openssl.html</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: After you have created these files, you will need to upload the .cer file to Azure via the "Upload" action of the "Settings" tab of the management portal[management-portal], and you will need to make note of where you saved the .pem file.
trans-unit.target: After you have created these files, you will need to upload the .cer file to Azure via the "Upload" action of the "Settings" tab of the management portal[management-portal], and you will need to make note of where you saved the .pem file.

trans-unit.source: After you have obtained your subscription ID, created a certificate, and uploaded the .cer file to Azure, you can connect to the Azure management endpoint by passing the subscription id and the path to the .pem file to ServiceManagementService:
trans-unit.target: After you have obtained your subscription ID, created a certificate, and uploaded the .cer file to Azure, you can connect to the Azure management endpoint by passing the subscription id and the path to the .pem file to ServiceManagementService:

trans-unit.source: In the example above, sms is a ServiceManagementService object.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, sms is a ServiceManagementService object.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceManagementService class is the primary class used to manage Azure services.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceManagementService class is the primary class used to manage Azure services.

trans-unit.source: Management certificates on Windows (MakeCert)
trans-unit.target: Management certificates on Windows (MakeCert)

trans-unit.source: You can create a self-signed management certificate on your machine using makecert.exe.
trans-unit.target: You can create a self-signed management certificate on your machine using makecert.exe.

trans-unit.source: Open a Visual Studio command prompt as an administrator and use the following command, replacing AzureCertificate with the certificate name you would like to use.
trans-unit.target: Open a Visual Studio command prompt as an administrator and use the following command, replacing AzureCertificate with the certificate name you would like to use.

trans-unit.source: The command will create the .cer file, and install it in the Personal certificate store.
trans-unit.target: The command will create the .cer file, and install it in the Personal certificate store.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see <link><linkText>Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more details, see <link><linkText>Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: After you have created the certificate, you will need to upload the .cer file to Azure via the "Upload" action of the "Settings" tab of the management portal[management-portal].
trans-unit.target: After you have created the certificate, you will need to upload the .cer file to Azure via the "Upload" action of the "Settings" tab of the management portal[management-portal].

trans-unit.source: After you have obtained your subscription ID, created a certificate, and uploaded the .cer file to Azure, you can connect to the Azure management endpoint by passing the subscription id and the location of the certificate in your Personal certificate store to ServiceManagementService (again, replace AzureCertificate with the name of your certificate):
trans-unit.target: After you have obtained your subscription ID, created a certificate, and uploaded the .cer file to Azure, you can connect to the Azure management endpoint by passing the subscription id and the location of the certificate in your Personal certificate store to ServiceManagementService (again, replace AzureCertificate with the name of your certificate):

trans-unit.source: In the example above, sms is a ServiceManagementService object.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, sms is a ServiceManagementService object.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceManagementService class is the primary class used to manage Azure services.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceManagementService class is the primary class used to manage Azure services.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: List available locations
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: List available locations

trans-unit.source: To list the locations that are available for hosting services, use the list\_locations method:
trans-unit.target: To list the locations that are available for hosting services, use the list\_locations method:

trans-unit.source: When you create a cloud service or storage service you will need to provide a valid location.
trans-unit.target: When you create a cloud service or storage service you will need to provide a valid location.

trans-unit.source: The list\_locations method will always return an up-to-date list of the currently available locations.
trans-unit.target: The list\_locations method will always return an up-to-date list of the currently available locations.

trans-unit.source: As of this writing, the available locations are:
trans-unit.target: As of this writing, the available locations are:

trans-unit.source: West Europe
trans-unit.target: West Europe

trans-unit.source: North Europe
trans-unit.target: North Europe

trans-unit.source: Southeast Asia
trans-unit.target: Southeast Asia

trans-unit.source: East Asia
trans-unit.target: East Asia

trans-unit.source: Central US
trans-unit.target: Central US

trans-unit.source: North Central US
trans-unit.target: North Central US

trans-unit.source: South Central US
trans-unit.target: South Central US

trans-unit.source: West US
trans-unit.target: West US

trans-unit.source: East US
trans-unit.target: East US

trans-unit.source: Japan East
trans-unit.target: Japan East

trans-unit.source: Japan West
trans-unit.target: Japan West

trans-unit.source: Brazil South
trans-unit.target: Brazil South

trans-unit.source: Australia East
trans-unit.target: Australia East

trans-unit.source: Australia Southeast
trans-unit.target: Australia Southeast

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a cloud service
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a cloud service

trans-unit.source: When you create an application and run it in Azure, the code and configuration together are called an Azure [cloud service] (known as a hosted service in earlier Azure releases).
trans-unit.target: When you create an application and run it in Azure, the code and configuration together are called an Azure [cloud service] (known as a hosted service in earlier Azure releases).

trans-unit.source: The create\_hosted\_service method allows you to create a new hosted service by providing a hosted service name (which must be unique in Azure), a label (automatically encoded to base64), a description and a location.
trans-unit.target: The create\_hosted\_service method allows you to create a new hosted service by providing a hosted service name (which must be unique in Azure), a label (automatically encoded to base64), a description and a location.

trans-unit.source: You can list all the hosted services for your subscription with the list\_hosted\_services method:
trans-unit.target: You can list all the hosted services for your subscription with the list\_hosted\_services method:

trans-unit.source: If you want to get information about a particular hosted service, you can do so by passing the hosted service name to the get\_hosted\_service\_properties method:
trans-unit.target: If you want to get information about a particular hosted service, you can do so by passing the hosted service name to the get\_hosted\_service\_properties method:

trans-unit.source: After you have created a cloud service, you can deploy your code to the service with the create\_deployment method.
trans-unit.target: After you have created a cloud service, you can deploy your code to the service with the create\_deployment method.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a cloud service
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a cloud service

trans-unit.source: You can delete a cloud service by passing the service name to the delete\_hosted\_service method:
trans-unit.target: You can delete a cloud service by passing the service name to the delete\_hosted\_service method:

trans-unit.source: Note that before you can delete a service, all deployments for the the service must first be deleted.
trans-unit.target: Note that before you can delete a service, all deployments for the the service must first be deleted.

trans-unit.source: (See <link><linkText>How to: Delete a deployment</linkText><title></title></link> for details.)
trans-unit.target: (See <link><linkText>How to: Delete a deployment</linkText><title></title></link> for details.)

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a deployment
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a deployment

trans-unit.source: To delete a deployment, use the delete\_deployment method.
trans-unit.target: To delete a deployment, use the delete\_deployment method.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to delete a deployment named v1.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to delete a deployment named v1.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a storage service
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a storage service

trans-unit.source: A [storage service] gives you access to Azure <link><linkText>Blobs[azure-blobs]</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>Tables[azure-tables]</linkText><title></title></link>, and <link><linkText>Queues[azure-queues]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: A [storage service] gives you access to Azure <link><linkText>Blobs[azure-blobs]</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>Tables[azure-tables]</linkText><title></title></link>, and <link><linkText>Queues[azure-queues]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To create a storage service, you need a name for the service (between 3 and 24 lowercase characters and unique within Azure), a description, a label (up to 100 characters, automatically encoded to base64), and a location.
trans-unit.target: To create a storage service, you need a name for the service (between 3 and 24 lowercase characters and unique within Azure), a description, a label (up to 100 characters, automatically encoded to base64), and a location.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a storage service by specifying a location.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a storage service by specifying a location.

trans-unit.source: Note in the example above that the status of the create\_storage\_account operation can be retrieved by passing the result returned by create\_storage\_account to the get\_operation\_status method.
trans-unit.target: Note in the example above that the status of the create\_storage\_account operation can be retrieved by passing the result returned by create\_storage\_account to the get\_operation\_status method.

trans-unit.source: You can list your storage accounts and their properties with the list\_storage\_accounts method:
trans-unit.target: You can list your storage accounts and their properties with the list\_storage\_accounts method:

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a storage service
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a storage service

trans-unit.source: You can delete a storage service by passing the storage service name to the delete\_storage\_account method.
trans-unit.target: You can delete a storage service by passing the storage service name to the delete\_storage\_account method.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a storage service will delete all data stored in the service (blobs, tables and queues).
trans-unit.target: Deleting a storage service will delete all data stored in the service (blobs, tables and queues).

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: List available operating systems
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: List available operating systems

trans-unit.source: To list the operating systems that are available for hosting services, use the list\_operating\_systems method:
trans-unit.target: To list the operating systems that are available for hosting services, use the list\_operating\_systems method:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use the list\_operating\_system\_families method, which groups the operating systems by family:
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use the list\_operating\_system\_families method, which groups the operating systems by family:

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create an operating system image
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create an operating system image

trans-unit.source: To add an operating system image to the image repository, use the add\_os\_image method:
trans-unit.target: To add an operating system image to the image repository, use the add\_os\_image method:

trans-unit.source: To list the operating system images that are available, use the list\_os\_images method.
trans-unit.target: To list the operating system images that are available, use the list\_os\_images method.

trans-unit.source: This includes all platform images and user images:
trans-unit.target: This includes all platform images and user images:

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete an operating system image
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete an operating system image

trans-unit.source: To delete a user image, use the delete\_os\_image method:
trans-unit.target: To delete a user image, use the delete\_os\_image method:

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Create a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: To create a virtual machine, you first need to create a <link><linkText>cloud service</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To create a virtual machine, you first need to create a <link><linkText>cloud service</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Then create the virtual machine deployment using the create\_virtual\_machine\_deployment method:
trans-unit.target: Then create the virtual machine deployment using the create\_virtual\_machine\_deployment method:

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to: Delete a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: To delete a virtual machine, you first delete the deployment using the delete\_deployment method:
trans-unit.target: To delete a virtual machine, you first delete the deployment using the delete\_deployment method:

trans-unit.source: The cloud service can then be deleted using the delete\_hosted\_service method:
trans-unit.target: The cloud service can then be deleted using the delete\_hosted\_service method:

trans-unit.source: How To: Create a Virtual Machine from a Captured Virtual Machine Image
trans-unit.target: How To: Create a Virtual Machine from a Captured Virtual Machine Image

trans-unit.source: To capture a VM image, you first call the capture\_vm\_image method:
trans-unit.target: To capture a VM image, you first call the capture\_vm\_image method:

trans-unit.source: Next, to make sure that you have successfully captured the image, use the list\_vm\_images api and make sure your image is displayed in the results:
trans-unit.target: Next, to make sure that you have successfully captured the image, use the list\_vm\_images api and make sure your image is displayed in the results:

trans-unit.source: To finally create the virtual machine using the captured image, use the create\_virtual\_machine\_deployment method as before, but this time pass in the vm_image_name instead
trans-unit.target: To finally create the virtual machine using the captured image, use the create\_virtual\_machine\_deployment method as before, but this time pass in the vm_image_name instead

trans-unit.source: To learn more about how to capture a Linux Virtual Machine, see <link><linkText>How to Capture a Linux Virtual Machine.</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: To learn more about how to capture a Linux Virtual Machine, see <link><linkText>How to Capture a Linux Virtual Machine.</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: To learn more about how to capture a Windows Virtual Machine, see <link><linkText>How to Capture a Windows Virtual Machine.</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: To learn more about how to capture a Windows Virtual Machine, see <link><linkText>How to Capture a Windows Virtual Machine.</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Next Steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of service management, you can access the <link><linkText>Complete API reference documentation for the Azure Python SDK</linkText><title></title></link> and perform complex tasks easily to manage your python application.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of service management, you can access the <link><linkText>Complete API reference documentation for the Azure Python SDK</linkText><title></title></link> and perform complex tasks easily to manage your python application.

trans-unit.target: test
